content.text: As a small team using cloud services, our contingency procedures are straightforward. Most of the heavy lifting is handled by AWS and Google, but you still need to know when to raise the alarm and who to contact.
You should immediately contact leadership if you experience any of these situations:

items: **Service Outages**: Can't access ClearTriage application, AWS services are down, or Google Drive is unavailable
**Access Issues**: Unable to log into AWS Console or Google Drive when you need to perform your duties
**Security Incidents**: Suspicious activity, potential breach, or any security concern
**Lost or Stolen Devices**: Any company device or personal device with ClearTriage access goes missing

content.title: Time is Critical
content.text: Don't wait to see if the problem resolves itself. If something seems wrong with our core services or security, report it immediately. False alarms are better than delayed responses.
When you need to report an issue, follow this contact order:

items: **Pete** (CTO) - First point of contact for all technical and security issues
**Savvy** (Senior Engineer/DevOps) - Contact if both Pete and Dave are unavailable

content.text: Use whatever communication method gets the fastest response - Slack, phone call, or text. For urgent security issues, don't hesitate to call directly.
Keep everyone's contact info saved in your phone. During an incident is not the time to be searching for phone numbers.
Here's the good news: because we use FedRAMP-authorized services (Li-SaaS), we don't need complex contingency plans. AWS and Google handle the heavy infrastructure work for us.

items: **AWS handles**: Server redundancy, automatic backups, disaster recovery, infrastructure monitoring
**Google handles**: Drive backups, version history, availability across regions
**We handle**: Monitoring our application, responding to incidents, maintaining access controls

content.title: Reduced Contingency Planning with Li-SaaS
content.text: Li-SaaS significantly reduces our contingency planning burden. While AWS and Google handle infrastructure recovery, we still maintain simple procedures for application-level recovery and communication.
This doesn't mean we're off the hook entirely. We still need to:

items: Monitor service status pages for AWS and Google
Have a communication plan (which you just learned above)
Know how to restore data from backups if needed
Keep customer contact information accessible outside our main systems

content.text: Your role in contingency response is simple but important:

items: Report immediately using the contact order above
Follow any instructions from leadership during an incident
Resume normal operations once the all-clear is given

content.text: You don't need to troubleshoot AWS infrastructure or figure out complex recovery procedures. Just alert the right people quickly so they can coordinate the response.
